#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk kexec-tools
exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: kexec-tools bug fix and enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description: The kexec-tools packages contain the /sbin/kexec binary and utilities that together form the user-space component of the kernel's kexec feature. The /sbin/kexec binary facilitates a new kernel to boot using the kernel's kexec feature either on a normal or a panic reboot. The kexec fastboot mechanism allows booting a Linux kernel from the context of an already running kernel. The kexec-tools packages have been upgraded to upstream version 2.0.7 and the makedumpfile subpackage has been upgraded to upstream version 1.5.7. The upstream versions provide a number of bug fixes and enhancements over the previous versions. (BZ#1099753, BZ#1144217) This update also fixes the following bugs: The IPADDR value in network configuration files located in the /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ directory is used to configure the IP address. Previously, the kdump service could not recognize and handle IP addresses if they were specified by the IPADDR[0~n] value. As a consequence, such an IP address was ignored by kdump. With this update, the "ip addr show NIC permanent" command is used to get the IP address, which avoids analyzing network configuration files, and kdump now recognizes all IP addresses as expected. (BZ#872013) When mounting a disk under the /var/ directory without specifying the path to the disk in the /etc/kdump.conf file, the vmcore file was incorrectly located in the disk's /var/crash/ directory instead of the /crash/ directory. The underlying source code has been modified to fix this bug, and vmcore is now located in the correct directory. (BZ#1173177) In addition, this update adds the following enhancements: The firmware-assisted dump (fadump) is an alternative mechanism to the kdump service. This update modifies the kdump init script to be aware of fadump. As a result, the userspace utility works the same with kdump and fadump. (BZ#731491) This update adds an add-on to the Anaconda installer that allows the user to select the firmware assisted dump (fadump) as a default dump mechanism on systems with the 64-bit PowerPC architecture. (BZ#868341) With this enhancement, the makedumpfile utility is able to estimate the size of a dumped vmcore file. (BZ#979473) The firstboot utility, which included the kdump setup, was replaced by the Anaconda add-on, which is an extension of the framework provided by the Anaconda installer. With this update, the kdump setup is integrated to Anaconda. (BZ#1070558) With this update, the fence_kdump configuration for generic clusters is supported. (BZ#1086988) This enhancement adds support for Extensible Firmware Interface (EFI) runtime services to the kdump service. (BZ#1099413) This update introduces a new kexec system call to support the kdump service on machines with the secure boot enabled. (BZ#1138453) With this update, the kdump service is now supported on systems with the Red Hat Enterprise Linux for POWER, little endian architecture. (BZ#1139864) Users of kexec-tools are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs and add these enhancements. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
